The Chief Information Officer (CIO) of an organization is concerned that the current locally-hosted, software threat solution is not agile enough. The CIO points to specific examples of zero-day threats that have recently taken a day or more to receive patches. The IT team is tasked with finding a solution that has a better chance of stopping emerging threats and stopping zero-day threats more quickly.
Which of the following solutions would have the BEST chance of meeting these goals?

discussion.content:
Out of all the possible answers listed, A would be the best option, but in this day and age with even SOHO grade hardware-based firewalls (see SonicWall range as an example) the Stateful firewalls (as to not being stateless firewalls - see link below) feature is already the norm and included in any firewall product range described as 'next-generation' firewalls (NGFW). 

The gist here is that opting for a 'Stateful firewall' as an additional security measure would be a moot topic as all most modern firewall products have the feature already as standard. 

This is not 2001.

Anyhow, further reading (if a stateless is still deemed a viable option these days):

Stateful vs. Stateless Firewalls

questions.question_text:
A company is moving into a larger office space. A site survey is performed, a network layout is created, and access points are placed throughout the building.
Which of the following steps should the network technician take NEXT to ensure blanket wireless coverage?

choices.A: Block all LAN to LAN traffic
choices.B: Block all LAN to WAN traffic
choices.D: Block all WLAN to WAN traffic
choices.C: Block all WAN to LAN traffic

questions.question_text:
A technician is configuring a computer lab at a school. The computers need to be able to communicate with each other, but students using the computers should not be able to access the internet.
Which of the following rules on the firewall should the technician configure for the lab computers?

discussion.content: Answer "C" is not the best answer. Let's look at all the answers, in order for lab computers within the LAN to communicate, LAN-LAN traffic is necessary, so don't pick A, don't block LAN-LAN! The Q doesn't mention WiFi, so D is not the best answer. They want to block in->out traffic, from the LAN to the internet, in this case the WAN must be assumed to be the internet for any question to work. Blocking in->out, or LAN to WAN, is the best answer, B. You can block out->in if done correctly, but outgoing traffic would still traverse your internet pipe. Why have extra traffic going OUT the internet if you are only going to block it coming back? The BEST answer is block it before it leaves, keeping unnecessary WAN traffic off your internet connection. Thus B is the BEST answer. Don't memorize Qs. KNOW THE WHYS and you'll do great on the exam!

comments.content: I'm glad you clarified this because I was confused when B was labeled the wrong answer
